feature: Early sharp positive transient (occurrence t≈0–8): Manifestation: rapid rise from baseline to a local maximum. Observed amplitude range across samples: approx +0.4 to +3.3 (sample-dependent). Morphology: single steep peak with little high-frequency jitter (smooth rise then quick fall in first 8–12 time steps). Time-frequency: concentrated energy in the lowest frequency rows (0 Hz row and immediate adjacent low-frequency rows) during the early window. Heatmap colors: predominantly red in the lowest-frequency rows for several samples (Samples 1, 2, 4), indicating the early positive transient is considered a typical feature for the label; occasional weak blue markings in adjacent intermediate-frequency rows indicate small atypical contributions in some samples. Classification: Typical when low-frequency (0–~0.03) band is red; atypical or ambiguous when mid-frequency rows show blue or mixed coloring.

Early-to-mid deep negative valley / prolonged trough (occurrence t≈8–30 / central early phase): Manifestation: a pronounced downward deflection below y=0 (baseline), often the largest negative excursion in the trace. Observed amplitude range: approx -1.0 to -2.6. Morphology: broad valley occupying many time steps (gradual descent then plateau/slow recovery), low volatility (smooth), sometimes with small oscillations at the trough. Time-frequency: strong energy concentrated at low-frequency rows (dominant), occasionally some spread into adjacent intermediate frequencies when small oscillations are present. Heatmap colors: predominantly red in the very-low-frequency region for Samples 1 and 4 (indicating a typical negative trough feature for the label). In some samples (e.g., Sample 3) the mid-frequency rows during this phase show mixed or weak blue, producing ambiguous classification for the oscillatory components. Classification: Tends to be a typical feature (low-freq red) unless intermediate-frequency components are blue, which indicates atypical jitter components.

Mid recovery / positive hump (occurrence t≈30–60): Manifestation: recovery from the deep valley to values at or above baseline; often a broad positive hump/plateau centered t≈34–60 with moderate amplitude. Observed amplitude range: approx 0.2 to ~1.2. Morphology: smoother, sustained positive level compared with short sharp peaks; sometimes a local maxima around t≈34–50. Time-frequency: again dominated by low-frequency energy for the sustained hump; when the recovery is smooth energy stays concentrated in 0 Hz row and adjacent low-frequency rows; if the recovery includes jitter, energy spreads upward into intermediate frequencies. Heatmap colors: generally red at the lowest-frequency rows (samples 1, 2, 4) indicating this recovery/plateau is a typical feature; intermediate-frequency contributions may be lightly red or mixed (ambiguous). Classification: Typical in its low-frequency components; intermediate-frequency variations may be ambiguous or slightly atypical.

Late secondary positive peak or sustained elevated plateau (occurrence t≈60–95, present in some samples): Manifestation: either a smaller continuing positive plateau or a distinct late positive peak (notably in Sample 2 around t≈85–92 and Sample 3 moderate plateau t≈50–80). Observed amplitude range: approx +0.2 to +3.0 (sample 2 shows a large late spike). Morphology: can be an abrupt late spike (sharp) or broad sustained elevated amplitude (smooth plateau). Time-frequency: when abrupt, energy appears in low frequency plus some intermediate-frequency spread (reflecting faster change); when broad/smooth, energy remains in lowest-frequency rows. Heatmap colors: large late peaks in Sample 2 have strong red in very-low-frequency rows and also red in some adjacent rows (typical); some samples show neutral or slight blue in intermediate rows, indicating partial atypicality. Classification: generally typical (low-frequency red) for sustained elevation; sharp late spikes may contain mixed typical/atypical signatures (red low-freq plus blue intermediate-freq).

Intermediate-frequency spread and jitter components (occurrence typically during transitions t≈10–40 and during abrupt late peaks t≈75–95): Manifestation: small oscillations / increased high-frequency content superimposed on peaks or transitions (visible as broader frequency spread in STFT). Time-frequency: energy spreads upward into intermediate (≈0.1–0.3) frequency rows; severity reflected by how many adjacent frequency rows carry energy. Heatmap colors: often mixed — many intermediate rows show blue or alternating red/blue strips (Samples 1, 3 show mixed/blue in mid-frequency bands). Classification: These intermediate frequency components are frequently atypical or ambiguous (blue or mixed coloring), meaning the model treats jittery/high-frequency content as less typical and possibly indicative of non-label-0 patterns.

High-frequency (upper rows >~0.3) weak components: Manifestation: minor, sparse high-frequency energy (small, short-lived). Heatmap colors: generally near-zero contributions (white) or occasional faint red/blue but not dominant. Classification: Not important; ambiguous or neutral for classification in these samples.
pattern: Sample 1 (Sample ID '10'): Early phase (t≈0–8) sharp positive transient (amplitude up to ≈+3.2) — mapped to concentrated low-frequency energy and marked red on heatmap (typical). Early-mid phase (t≈8–28) broad deep negative trough (down to ≈-2.2) — dominant low-frequency STFT energy also marked red (typical). Mid phase (t≈30–55) recovery to a sustained positive hump (≈0.6–1.0) — low-frequency energy red (typical). Late phase (t>70) minor oscillatory fluctuations around baseline — some intermediate-frequency rows show weak blue (atypical) while lowest-frequency remains neutral, indicating these small late jitters are less typical. Overall: dominant low-frequency large-amplitude deviations (both positive spike and broad negative valley and recovery hump) are treated as typical (red), while higher-frequency jitter components are ambiguous/atypical (blue or mixed).

Sample 2 (Sample ID '4'): Early short positive spike (t≈0–6) modest amplitude (typical due to low-frequency red). Early-mid long negative descent and broad trough (t≈8–40) amplitude down to ≈-1.6 — strong low-frequency energy red (typical). Middle-late recovery to baseline and then a pronounced late large positive peak (t≈85–92, amplitude up to ≈+3.0) — STFT shows strong low-frequency energy for the late spike and heatmap marks the very-low-frequency rows red (typical). Intermediate-frequency bands across transitions show mixed coloring (some blue), especially during transitions to the late spike — these are atypical or ambiguous contributions. Overall pattern: two major low-frequency events (early trough and late spike) drive classification as label 0 and are typical; superposed mid-frequency components during transitions are less informative or atypical.

Sample 3 (Sample ID '12'): Early deep negative baseline deviation (t≈0–20, amplitude to ≈-2.2) — strong low-frequency energy, heatmap shows red at the lowest frequency rows (typical for the trough). Mid transition (t≈30–45) upward slope crossing baseline into a sustained positive plateau (t≈45–80) with moderate amplitude ≈0.8–1.2 — low-frequency energy again important and partly red but the heatmap contains more mixed/blue patches in the intermediate-frequency rows during the transition, indicating the oscillatory/transition components are ambiguous/atypical. Late mild decay back to baseline (t>80) with negligible heatmap contribution. Overall: a canonical pattern of deep initial trough (typical) + smooth recovery to sustained positive plateau (typical in low-frequency band) with transition-related intermediate-frequency components being ambiguous or atypical.

Sample 4 (Sample ID '42'): Early high positive transient (t≈0–6, ≈+2.0) followed immediately by a strong descent to a broad negative valley (t≈6–30 down to ≈-2.3) — both events produce concentrated low-frequency energy (STFT) and are marked red in the heatmap's lowest-frequency rows (typical). Mid recovery and broad positive hump around t≈34–60 (≈+0.4–0.9) with low-frequency red contributions (typical). Late small bump around t≈70–79 is visible with mixed low/intermediate-frequency coloring (slight red in low-freq and near-neutral elsewhere) — considered typical in its slow component but any higher-frequency detail is ambiguous/atypical. Overall pattern: the sequence of early positive spike + large negative trough + mid recovery hump, dominated by low-frequency energy, corresponds to the heatmap's red low-frequency region and therefore constitutes the model's typical signature for this label; intermediate-frequency spread during rapid transitions is not consistently typical (mixed/blue).

feature: Early small positive transient (occurrence: time steps ~0-8). Manifestation: short-duration positive peak or bump immediately at the start of the heartbeat trace (amplitude range across samples ~0.4 to 3.3 depending on sample). Time-frequency mapping: concentrated energy in the lowest frequency rows (0 Hz row and the first few adjacent low-frequency rows) during the same early time window. Heatmap color mapping: predominantly light-red to red in many samples (Samples 0, 7, 19) for low-frequency rows at the early window, indicating that this early positive transient is a typical feature of label 1 in those samples; in Sample 2 the very lowest-frequency cell at the early window shows a blue patch (atypical) mixed with red elsewhere (ambiguous for that sample). Classification: typically a typical feature (red) for most samples, with occasional atypical/ambiguous markings in Sample 2 at the absolute lowest frequency row.

Deep negative valley / baseline drop (occurrence: time steps ~12-36). Manifestation: a pronounced downward deflection (valley) often reaching below -1, frequently as deep as -2 to -2.6 (magnitude varies across samples), fairly wide in duration (tens of time-steps) and morphologically smooth (slow trough rather than very sharp spike). Time-frequency mapping: strong low-frequency energy localized in the 0 Hz row and adjacent low-frequency rows for the time window corresponding to the valley; energy sometimes spreads to intermediate frequency rows if the trough contains small jitter. Heatmap color mapping: strongly red in the 0 Hz and adjacent low-frequency rows in Samples 0, 7, and 19 (indicating the deep valley is a typical signature for label 1). In Sample 2 the same valley time window includes both red and some blue in the very lowest-frequency cell(s) (mixed typical/atypical), so that sample shows partial atypicality at the absolute lowest-frequency component. Classification: generally a typical feature (red) — the deep negative valley is the primary canonical feature for label 1 — with occasional atypical contributions at the 0 Hz row in some samples (ambiguous in Sample 2).

Recovery / rising hump after the valley (occurrence: time steps ~36-55). Manifestation: relatively rapid recovery from the valley, crossing up through y=0, often producing a positive hump or plateau (amplitude ~0.5–1.2) with reduced volatility compared to the initial transient. Time-frequency mapping: low-frequency energy concentrated during the ramp-up time window; sometimes intermediate frequencies have small energy if the recovery is jagged. Heatmap color mapping: mostly light-red / mild red across low-frequency rows in Samples 0, 7 and 19 (typical). In Sample 2 this mid-stage recovery also contains mixed red/blue at low-to-intermediate frequencies (ambiguous). Classification: typically interpreted by the model as a positive, label-1 feature for most samples, though less strongly typical than the deep valley itself.

Late-stage small amplitude baseline/plateau (occurrence: time steps ~60-95). Manifestation: after recovery there is a longer duration, low-amplitude positive plateau with small fluctuations and occasional small peaks/jitters (amplitude ~0.0 to 1.0). Time-frequency mapping: low-frequency energy reduced compared to the trough; mid-to-low frequency rows show gentle energy. Heatmap color mapping: mixed: Samples 0 and 7 show near-neutral to slight-red contribution in low-frequency rows (weakly typical); Sample 2 shows stronger red in some late windows (typical) and Sample 19 shows red concentrated in a later low-frequency block (typical). Classification: generally a weakly typical feature (model sometimes relies on these steady positive plateaus as supportive evidence), but in some time-frequency bands it is ambiguous.

Late sharp positive spike (occurrence: time steps ~85-95 in some samples, e.g., Sample 19 and Sample 2). Manifestation: an abrupt high-amplitude positive peak (Sample 19 reaches ~3.3 at ~90; Sample 2 has a late-rise near 90 reaching ~1.9). Time-frequency mapping: this produces concentrated low-frequency energy (if the spike is smooth) and additional higher-frequency energy if the spike has steep flanks or jitter. Heatmap color mapping: Sample 19 shows red at low-frequency rows in the later window (typical); Sample 2 also shows red in later windows (typical). Classification: when present, the late spike in these samples is treated as a typical feature by the model (red), suggesting that large positive late deflections can be part of the normal heartbeat label in this dataset.

Short-scale jitter and intermediate-frequency content (occurrence: various, often during recovery or late plateau). Manifestation: small rapid oscillations superimposed on the main waveform (higher local variance). Time-frequency mapping: energy spreads to intermediate and higher frequency rows (broader frequency-band footprint). Heatmap color mapping: frequently light-blue or mixed blue/red in the intermediate frequency rows (indicates occasional atypical contributions). Classification: jitter and higher-frequency content are sometimes considered atypical (blue) or ambiguous, especially when they appear in the mid-late time windows — the model regards such distributed high-frequency energy with caution.

Overall baseline and morphology: baseline is offset around zero with pronounced negative trough then recovery to positive plateau. Manifestation: consistent sequence across samples: early positive bump → deep negative valley → recovery positive hump → low-amplitude plateau (with optional late spike). Heatmap color mapping: the core low-frequency valley and recovery are predominantly red (typical); higher-frequency distributed content and some very-low-frequency anomalies (single-cell blue spots at the 0 Hz row) are atypical or ambiguous depending on sample. Classification: the canonical morphological sequence (valley then recovery) is treated as typical for label 1 by the model.

peak: Very large late positive spike (occurrence: ~t=86-92). Manifestation: abrupt high-amplitude positive peak reaching >3.0 (line plot). Time-frequency: strong energy concentrated in the lowest-frequency rows during the same late window, but importantly also showing energy in adjacent intermediate-frequency rows (STFT). Heatmap marking: red across low-frequency rows and noticeable red in intermediate-frequency rows in the late window. Interpretation: typical feature (model treats both low- and some intermediate-frequency components of this late spike as supportive/typical).

other (post-peak rapid rebound): Rapid negative rebound immediately following the late spike (occurrence: ~t=92-96). Manifestation: sharp fall from the late positive peak down to ~-0.6 to -0.8 within a few time-steps (line plot), i.e., a short-duration negative trough following the spike. Time-frequency: localized energy in the same late-time window (STFT shows continued energy across low-to-intermediate frequencies). Heatmap marking: low-frequency rows in the late-time block that include the rebound are marked red (the model treats this short post-spike rebound as part of the typical late-stage signature for this sample). Interpretation: typical feature (not flagged as atypical here).
pattern: Sample 0 pattern: Early small positive transient (~t=0-8) (amplitude ~0.4–3.3) (low-frequency red → typical) + Deep negative valley (~t=12-32) (amplitude down to ~-2.2) (strong 0Hz & adjacent low-frequency red → typical) + Recovery positive hump (~t=36-50) (amplitude up to ~1.1–1.2) (low-frequency light-red → typical) + Late low-amplitude plateau and small peaks (~t=60-95) (low-to-intermediate frequencies mostly neutral to slightly red → weakly typical). Overall: canonical valley-to-recovery morphology; model strongly relies on the low-frequency valley region (red) as the main typical identifier.

Sample 2 pattern: Early transient (~t=0-8) (positive bump; low-frequency mostly light-red but with a 0Hz blue cell → mixed/ambiguous) + Deep valley (~t=12-40) (amplitude ~-1.6) (low-frequency energy present but SHAP shows mixed red and an intense localized blue at the absolute lowest-frequency cell in the early-to-mid trough window → partially atypical/ambiguous) + Recovery and progressive long-term rise (~t=50-95) (crosses zero ~t=55 then rises to a late spike near t~90) (low-frequency and mid-low frequency red in later windows → typical) + Intermediate-frequency jitter present during recovery (intermediate rows show blue/neutral → atypical/ambiguous). Overall: similar morphological stages as other samples but the model marks the early trough's absolute lowest-frequency component as atypical (blue) while later positive ramp and late spike are interpreted as typical (red).

Sample 7 pattern: Small initial bump (~t=0-6) (low-frequency red → typical) + Deep valley (~t=8-32) (amplitude down to ~-2.4) (strong concentrated 0Hz & adjacent row red → typical) + Sharp recovery and stable positive plateau (~t=36-80) (moderate low-frequency red to neutral → typical/weakly typical) + Minimal high-frequency jitter (few blue cells at intermediate freq late) (atypical but minor). Overall: classic valley + recovery pattern where the trough low-frequency block is the primary typical marker for label 1.

Sample 19 pattern: Early positive bump (~t=0-6) (low-frequency red → typical) + Deep baseline drop (~t=12-26) (down to ~-2.2) (0Hz and adjacent low-frequency rows strongly red → typical) + Recovery and extended mid positive plateau (~t=34-70) (low-frequency energy persists; SHAP low-frequency cells are red → typical) + Late very large positive spike (~t=86-92) (amplitude >3.0) (low-frequency energy and SHAP red in later low-frequency rows → typical). Overall: canonical valley+recovery pattern with an additional late large positive spike that the model treats as typical for label 1 in this sample.

Aggregated pattern features for label 1: The consistent pattern across reference samples is the sequence: (1) an early small positive transient, (2) a pronounced low-frequency deep valley lasting many time-steps, (3) a recovery that crosses y=0 to a positive hump or plateau, and (4) a late-stage low-amplitude plateau or optional late spike. The time-frequency signature that the model treats as most typical (strong red) is concentrated at the lowest frequency rows (0Hz row and immediately adjacent low-frequency rows) during the deep-valley time window (approximately time steps ~12–36). Features that broaden into intermediate and higher frequency rows (jitter, sharp flanks, or irregular high-frequency oscillations) are treated as less typical or atypical (blue or mixed), and single-cell blue patches at the absolute 0Hz row in some samples (notably Sample 2) indicate that the model can flag some very-low-frequency deviations as atypical or confusing. In short, the model relies on low-frequency valley + recovery morphology as the canonical, typical fingerprint for label 1, while high-frequency spread and certain isolated 0Hz anomalies are treated as atypical or ambiguous.

Combined pattern for Sample 19 (supplementing preliminary summary): Early small positive transient (~t=0-6) (low-frequency red, typical) + Deep low-frequency valley (~t=8-26, down to ~-2.2 to -2.4) (strong 0Hz & adjacent low-frequency red, typical) + Recovery and extended mid positive plateau (~t=34-70) (low-frequency red to mild-red, typical) + Very large late positive spike (~t=86-92, >3.0) that contains not only strong low-frequency energy but also clear intermediate-frequency energy (both marked red → model treats these frequency components of the spike as typical) + Immediate post-spike rapid negative rebound (~t=92-96, down to ~-0.7) occurring within the same late-time block (low-frequency heatmap cells in this late block are red → treated as typical). In short: canonical valley→recovery pattern is present, plus a late-stage complex event consisting of a large spike with intermediate-frequency content and a sharp post-spike rebound — the model treats the whole late-event block (low + some intermediate frequencies) as typical for this sample.

feature: Early deep negative baseline / valley (time ~0–20): manifests as a sustained trough with values around -1.5 to -2.5 in the line plots (samples 12, 54, 58). In the time-frequency images this maps to strong low-frequency energy concentrated in the lowest row (0 Hz) and adjacent low-frequency rows (high energy because of large baseline deviation). In the SHAP heatmaps these early deep negative baselines are predominantly blue or blue-dominant in the low-to-mid frequency rows (0.05–0.15 region): classified as ATYPICAL (blue) features for label 0. This atypical early trough contributes to the model treating the sample as non-label-0.

Peak / mid positive plateau (time ~30–70): manifests as a rising trend crossing the zero line and stabilizing around +0.5 to +1.2 (samples 12, 54, 58). The STFT shows concentrated low-frequency energy (0 Hz row) during this plateau; occasionally adjacent low-frequency bands show energy. The SHAP heatmaps at the lowest frequency row for this mid-phase are mixed: often red at the 0 Hz row (indicating those low-frequency plateau components are typical of label 0) while adjacent low-frequency rows show weak positive or near-zero SHAP. Judgment: MIXED/AMBIGUOUS (red at 0Hz row but mixed in adjacent rows) — these mid-plateau low-frequency components partially support label-0 but are not decisive.

Late abrupt positive spike / transient peak (time ~80–92): manifests in samples 54 and 58 as a sharp upward transient peak reaching >2.0 and in sample 12 as a smaller positive activity ~+1.0 around later time steps. STFT shows a localized high-energy event again concentrated in the lowest frequency band and some spread into adjacent rows (short-duration energy). In SHAP heatmaps this late spike region is often weakly red in the very lowest-frequency row but can be mixed or weak overall in impact relative to the early trough (so labelled MIXED/weak red). Judgment: AMBIGUOUS (small red contribution but insufficiently dominant).

Transition/jitter regions around the crossing point (time ~25–40): line plots show a relatively fast upward slope (rate of change) with minor oscillations (small jitters). The STFT shows broader low-frequency spread (wider band in adjacent rows) when slope and jitter occur. SHAP shows both mild blue and mild red in adjacent frequency rows for these times (mixed). Judgment: AMBIGUOUS (confusing features that do not strongly anchor the model).

Low-frequency DC-dominance across entire recording: overall the strongest energy in STFT across samples is in the 0Hz row (baseline/slow trends) rather than high-frequency components. SHAP indicates the 0Hz rows sometimes strongly red in specific time windows (typical) but also blue in others (atypical). The alternation of red/blue on the 0Hz row across time is itself an ambiguous pattern that can cause misclassification when atypical (blue) windows outweigh typical ones. Judgment: AMBIGUOUS/ATYPICAL depending on the temporal balance (in these samples atypical early windows dominate).
pattern: Sample 12 (ID 12) pattern: Early deep negative baseline (time 0–20) with trough values around -1.6 to -2.3 (STFT: large low-frequency energy) (SHAP: BLUE dominant at low/adjacent frequency rows → ATYPICAL) + Mid-phase upward trend and sustained positive plateau (time 35–70) values ~+0.3 to +1.2 (STFT: low-frequency DC energy concentrated at 0Hz) (SHAP: RED at 0Hz row but mixed in adjacent rows → PARTIALLY TYPICAL / AMBIGUOUS) + Late small positive activity (time ~70–90) mild peak ~+0.7 (SHAP: weak red/near-zero) → overall pattern where the early strong atypical negative baseline (blue) counteracts mid-phase typical low-frequency evidence; model logits favor class 1 (predicted normal) because the atypical early trough produces a net negative SHAP contribution for label-0.

Sample 54 (ID 54) pattern: Pronounced early trough (time 0–20) reaching ~-2.3 (STFT: pronounced low-frequency energy) (SHAP: BLUE dominant at low-frequency rows → ATYPICAL) + Clear mid-to-late positive plateau (time 30–75) with values ~+0.4 to +1.0 (STFT: DC energy concentrated at 0Hz) (SHAP: RED for some 0Hz windows, but adjacent rows mixed) + Very late abrupt large positive spike (time 85–90) >+2.0 (STFT: short-duration high-energy in low-frequency rows) (SHAP: weak red or mixed) → combined pattern where the strong early atypical valley (blue) exerts a larger negative SHAP effect than the late/central red features; black-box logits strongly favor class 1 (largest margin among three), indicating the atypical early valley is especially influential for misclassification.

Sample 58 (ID 58) pattern: Early negative baseline (time 0–25) trough ~-1.0 to -2.1 (STFT: concentrated low-frequency energy) (SHAP: BLUE at low-mid frequency rows → ATYPICAL) + Rapid transition and long mid positive plateau (time 33–70) values ~+0.2 to +1.1 (STFT: DC band dominant) (SHAP: mixed with some red at 0Hz but blue in adjacent rows → AMBIGUOUS) + Late sharp positive spike (time ~86–90) large transient >+2.0 (STFT: low-frequency transient) (SHAP: mixed/weak red) → net effect: atypical early valley combined with mixed-frequency mid-phase produces confusion; black-box predicts class 1 with moderate margin.

Cross-sample summary (why misclassification happens): All three samples share a common boundary pattern: a strong low-frequency early negative valley (deep baseline deviation) that SHAP marks as atypical for label-0 (blue) plus subsequent low-frequency positive plateaus/spikes that are partially typical (red) but insufficient in magnitude or temporal extent to overcome the initial atypical signature. Because the model’s SHAP contributions are temporally uneven (early blue windows have large negative impact), the black-box’s logit sums favor the opposite class. Therefore the primary boundary-causing feature is the early deep trough mapped to low-frequency energy and flagged blue in heatmaps; secondary boundary features are mixed/ambiguous low-frequency plateaus and late spikes whose partial red contributions fail to correct the atypical early signature.

feature: Mid-phase deep negative valley (occurrence ~time steps 20–45 in plots): large amplitude troughs reaching approx. -1.0 to -2.0 (sample-dependent). Morphology: broad, sustained negative baseline (not a narrow spike) with relatively slow recovery. Time-frequency manifestation: strong low-frequency/near-DC energy concentrated in the 0 Hz row and the immediately adjacent low-frequency rows during the trough. Heatmap color: dominantly blue in the 0 Hz row (atypical) with mixed (red/blue) in adjacent low-frequency rows. Interpretation: model treats this prolonged negative baseline as atypical for label 1 and this feature is a primary driver of misclassification.

Early transient positive peak (occurrence ~time steps 0–10): sharp positive spike amplitude ranges ~+0.5 to +3.0 depending on sample. Morphology: short-duration transient (peak) at the beginning of the sequence in most samples. Time-frequency manifestation: concentrated low-frequency energy but sometimes some higher-frequency spread if the peak is sharp. Heatmap color: often red in adjacent low-frequency rows (considered typical for label 1) but occasionally shows small blue markings at the 0 Hz row if the transient is unusually large. Interpretation: by itself often supports label 1, but when paired with atypical mid-phase features it can contribute to confusion.

Late-phase elevated plateau / recovery (occurrence ~time steps 50–90): positive plateau or ramp with amplitudes ~+0.3 to +1.9. Morphology: gradual positive ramp and sustained higher-than-baseline values in the late phase. Time-frequency manifestation: low-frequency energy concentrated near 0 Hz and first few frequency bins. Heatmap color: mostly red (typical) in adjacent low-freq components; occasionally mixed coloring in some samples where late ramps produce ambiguous contributions. Interpretation: typically supports the normal label but does not fully overcome the atypical mid-phase trough in boundary cases.

Sharp slope / rapid transition (occurrence ~time steps ~35–55 in many samples): abrupt valley-to-rise transitions (fast rate-of-change). Morphology: steep ascending slopes from trough to plateau. Time-frequency manifestation: energy spreads into intermediate and higher low-frequency components (wider vertical spread in STFT) — i.e., broader low-to-mid-frequency band activity. Heatmap color: mixed red/blue across low and some intermediate frequency rows, indicating model confusion; sometimes blue dominant in the low-freq rows during the transition. Interpretation: these abrupt transitions increase frequency spread and the model often treats parts of that spread as atypical, contributing to misclassification.

Localized 0 Hz (DC) dominance (occurrence aligned with trough/time windows ~15–40 or narrow windows at peaks): concentrated energy solely at the 0 Hz row within time windows. Morphology: strong DC-like offset or very slow oscillation in that region (sustained offset). Time-frequency manifestation: very bright 0 Hz cell(s) in STFT. Heatmap color: frequently deep blue at the 0 Hz row (strongly atypical). Interpretation: the model especially penalizes sustained DC-like energy in these windows as non-characteristic of label 1.

Mixed-frequency jitter during transitions (occurrence mostly near slope regions): small high-frequency components superimposed on slope or peak (jitter). Morphology: minor oscillatory jitter or variability on top of main waveforms. Time-frequency manifestation: vertical extension of energy into higher rows (broader frequency coverage). Heatmap color: mixed (patchy red and blue) across higher rows — indicates ambiguity. Interpretation: jitter per se is not consistently typical/atypical but in boundary samples it increases confusion and can nudge the logit toward misclassification.
pattern: Sample ID 2 pattern: Early pronounced positive transient at t≈2–8 (+0.4 to +2.0) (low-frequency energy; heatmap mostly red in adjacent low-freq rows = typical) + Broad mid-phase deep negative valley at t≈20–44 (amplitude ≈ -1.2 to -1.7) with concentrated 0 Hz energy (heatmap strongly blue at 0 Hz and mixed in adjacent low-freq rows = atypical) + Late-phase recovery and rising plateau t≈50–90 (+0.3 to +1.9) (low-frequency energy, heatmap red = typical). Net effect: atypical mid trough (0 Hz blue) outweighs typical early/late features, producing boundary misclassification.

Sample ID 6 pattern: Early moderate positive peak t≈0–6 (+1.0–1.9) (low-freq energy; heatmap mostly red) + Extended mid trough t≈10–38 (amplitude to ≈ -1.0 to -1.8) with strong DC/0 Hz concentration (heatmap deep blue at 0 Hz, adjacent bins mixed) + Pronounced slope and jitter during recovery t≈40–60 (broadening energy to adjacent freq rows; heatmap mixed red/blue). Net effect: strong 0 Hz atypical marking in mid-phase combined with transition-derived frequency spread yields uncertain logits and misclassification.

Sample ID 41 pattern: Early negative-to-deep negative baseline t≈0–28 (sustained negative baseline ≈ -0.5 to -1.7) producing low-frequency energy; heatmap shows red in several low-freq rows but patchy blue at the 0 Hz row (partial atypical signal) + Abrupt rise around t≈34–45 to a long positive plateau t≈45–95 (amplitude ≈ +0.5–1.3) with concentrated low-freq energy (heatmap mostly red for late-phase) + Some intermediate-frequency structure near the rise (heatmap small blue patches). Net effect: mixture of partially atypical DC signatures and confused transition energy makes the sample borderline.

Sample ID 35 pattern: Very large early positive spike t≈2–6 (+1.0 to +3.2) (strong low-freq plus some higher-freq spread; heatmap shows red in adjacent low-freq but blue at 0 Hz in some windows) + Prominent mid negative trough t≈18–38 (to ≈ -2.0) with heavy 0 Hz dominance (heatmap deep blue at 0 Hz and mixed coloring in low freq rows = atypical) + Moderate late ramp/plateau t≈48–90 (heatmap largely red). Net effect: extreme amplitude early combined with a very strong atypical DC-like mid trough produces a strong boundary signal; the model's SHAP consistently flags the 0 Hz mid-trough as atypical and drives misclassification.
